question: To the halls of Tripoli, shitbirds.
answer: You come all the way down here to roust--

question: I came all the way down here same as you did. Keep from gettin' killed. Happened to see those jarheads beatin' on a good collar-- Habla Ingles, Tomas? Tom here's my ninth hard felon of the month. Six weeks he'll be sucking gas. In three years I'll be working Central Warrants. Jewboy Deputy D.A. over there wets his pants for fighters. Promised me the next spot he can wangle.
answer: Impressive.

question: Wanna hear something more impressive? My first twenty fights were stumblebums handpicked by my manager. My girlfriend saw you fight a couple times over at the Olympic. Says maybe you could take me.
answer: Whatta we do about the Mex?

question: We'll take 'em in the morning.
answer: You'll take him.

question: He's half yours, partner.
answer: He's all yours. And I'm not your partner.

question: Someday.
answer: Somethin' up, Tommy? His old man Fritzie's a Central Dick.

question: Read this aloud, Officer. It's running in Sunday's Times.
answer: "Before the war, the City of the Angels was graced with two local fighters, born and raised a scant five miles apart, pugilists with styles as different as fire and ice. Lee Blanchard was a bowlegged windmill of a leather slinger--

question: Skip down to the fire and ice part.
answer: "Mr. Fire and Mr. Ice never fought each other, but a sense of duty brought them together in spirit, and both joined the Los Angeles Police Department." Blanchard cracked the baffling Boulevard-Citizens bank robbery case in 1939 and captured thrill-killer Tomas Dos Santos; Bleichert served with distinction during the '43 Zoot Suit Wars--"

question: Skip to the end.
answer: "Both men made great sacrifices to serve their city, and on Election Day, voters are going to be asked to do the same thing--vote on a five million dollar bond proposal to upgrade the LAPD's equipment and provide for an eight percent pay raise for all personnel. Keep in mind the examples of Mr. Fire and Mr. Ice. Vote "Yes" on Proposition B."

question: Whattya think?
answer: Subtle.

question: Made me quit fighting the smokers. Didn't want me doin' the "vegetable shuffle."
answer: I'll try not to hurt you.

question: Sure make Loew happy.
answer: He's got money on me, I gather?

question: Seems that way.
answer: And if I win I get Warrants?

question: Seems that way.
answer: What do you think of all this, Miss Lake?

question: So...I'm surprised but I'm not so surprised. I hear you been lookin' good. Better'n people think.
answer: I'm not bettin' on me, Pete.

question: Oh. Then as a friend I feel it's my duty to tell you this
answer: Knockout between rounds eight and ten.

question: Dragna's got a guy really sold on you. Even money. Best you're gonna get.
answer: Thanks, Pete.

question: Luck.
answer: Short of winning?

question: At least he looks good with his shirt off.
answer: Where's your sketch pad?

question: I was never very good. Ended up with a degree in History. Masters. Lee's fight money paid for it.
answer: Education's an expensive habit to kick. He shouldn't have quit fighting.

question: I asked him to. Besides, catching animals gave him a sense of order. You have a girlfriend, Dwight?
answer: Saving myself for Rita Hayworth.

question: We're not getting married if that's what you're wondering.
answer: Why not? Shacking's against the regs. Probably cost him a stripe.

question: I have to go, Dwight. Good luck tomorrow night.
answer: You didn't answer my question--

question: You gonna hide in there another week? Ain't you bored yet?
answer: Gettin' there.

question: Wanna work Warrants with me?
answer: What?

question: Harrell's been callin' to tell you. You been hibernating--
answer: But I lost. Loew's deal--

question: Ready to roll, canvasback?
answer: Why'd you really quit fighting?

question: Benny Siegel bought out my contract, scared off my manager. Said he'd get me a shot at Joe Louis if I'd take two dives for him. I said no, joined the Department 'cuz Jew syndicate boys won't kill cops. Anything else?
answer: One more. What are we doin' here?

question: While you were dancing with Ellis at muster I checked Maynard Coleman's KA's on the bulletin and recognized the name of a fence. Think he tends bar here... Bruno Albanese? Police officers, Bruno. Let's make this fast so I don't have to watch you eat.
answer: Right there! Police officer. You're under arrest.

question: Ellis loves the kid angle.
answer: You talk to Ellis?

question: He's only "Ellis" to lieutenants on up, Blanchard.
answer: Least I don't call him "kike".

question: This grand tour stuff's for shit. I'm callin' in some favors. Got a tip. Snitch a mine says he's shacking with some poon in a crib near Slauson and Hoover.
answer: It's all colored down there--

question: We fuckin' roll. Hopheads. Let's shake 'em for an address or a name. Shut up, shitbird.
answer: Partner!

question: Bucky duck!
answer: He knew one of the guys. Baxter Fitch. Busted him once for loitering. Sort of liked the guy.

question: He knew one of the guys.
answer: Bobby DeWitt gets out in a week, Dwight. We're on edge. He swore at the trial he was going to kill Lee.

question: We can take care of Bobby DeWitt.
answer: Lee's scared. You don't know Bobby.

question: I know as much as I need to know.
answer: Rise and shine partner!

question: Lee? You okay?
answer: Sure. Ran Mulholland at a hundred and ten. Played house with Kay all day yesterday. Feel like doing some police work?

question: Keep going.
answer: Junior Nash's got a fuck pad on Norton and Coliseum. Okie trash.

question: Lee.
answer: Is that Millard and Sears?

question: whistles harshly with his fingers in his mouth. Before this gets out of hand let's put the kibosh on something. If this gets a lot of publicity we're going to get a lot of confessions. So we keep some things quiet. This girl was disemboweled. You keep this information to yourselves. Not your wives, not your girlfriends, no other officers.
answer: Nash is renting a room in that building over there.

question: Blood on the premises?
answer: No. This isn't him.

question: The lab'll be the judge of that.
answer: Hey. Junior Nash, remember?

question: Hey. Junior Nash, remember?
answer: He didn't do this.

question: No. He beat an old woman to death. That's why he's our priority warrantee.
answer: Not anymore.

question: This ain't ours, partner--
answer: It is now, partner.

question: ...anyone discarding women's clothing?
answer: ...seen anyone in the lot on 39th...

question: ...and what about this man? You were supposed to meet me at the fights tonight, remember?
answer: Priority. Remember.

question: Priority for the Bureau. Not for us.
answer: Nice white girl gets snuffed. Gotta show the voters they did the right thing passing the bond issue. It's a showcase. It's A-plus, Buck. We don't miss this.

question: We've had enough headlines for the week.
answer: With or without you, partner.

question: Here's what she wasn't. She wasn't raped, she wasn't pregnant, dried semen indicates voluntary intercourse within the last week...She took what I'd call a gentle whipping in the last ten days...In terms of the nitty-gritty...She was probably tortured with a knife for thirty- six to forty-eight hours before death. The cause of which is either the mouth wound or more likely she was beaten to death with something like a baseball bat.
answer: What about her insides?

question: They came out after death. Then I'd say he drained the blood from the body and washed it clean, probably in a bathtub.
answer: Did the guy know anything about medicine or anatomy?

question: Johnny on the spot at my job. Twenty- seven straight hours. Refrigerator repairman. Twenty-seven straight and the last seventeen overtime. Call my boss. He'll alibi me up tighter than a popcorn fart, and that's air tight.
answer: When was the last time you saw your daughter?

question: Betty came west in '43 with stars in her eyes. I promised her three squares and a five-spot if she kept the house tidy.
answer: Was that soldier her boyfriend?

question: She's a smart woman.
answer: Hi, Dwight.

question: How'd you know it was me?
answer: Lee stomps, you tread lightly.

question: Lee's--
answer: Let me guess...Lee's up all night-- probably on Benzedrine again--working that poor girl's murder-- You're worried about him. And he's worried about me. But who's worried about you? Is that left for me?

question: No need for that.
answer: For such a cautious man you're quite a hardcase.

question: It's just...He's done a lot for me.
answer: Found it in storage down at the railway. Carbons of mash notes to sailors. Hundreds of 'em. Thank our friend Bevo Means at the Herald. Bevo's painting Betty and her black dress like some actress in that Alan Ladd movie, The Blue Dahlia. Should triple our confessions.

question: Great. I think I want to go back to Warrants.
answer: No dice. You're a bright penny and I want you here. Betty's last known residences and KA's. Go to University Station and pick up Bill Koenig. Fritzie's sick. Keep Bill on a tight leash, and you write the report because Billy's practically illiterate.

question: Lieutenant--
answer: Call me Russ and get out of here.

question: Let's try talk job. Miss Saddon?
answer: You the driver from RKO?

question: Police.
answer: If this is about those jaywalking--

question: It's about Elizabeth Short.
answer: I did all this on the phone this morning. Nine thousand questions about Betty's nine thousand boyfriends and I don't remember any of the names. Can I go now? The extras truck is due any minute.

question: How about you sit dawn and answer my questions or I bust you for the reefer you flushed.
answer: That's Betty's other place. DeLongpre and Orange.

question: She moved around quite a bit. You know why? Was somebody threatening her?
answer: Betty's problem wasn't enemies. It was too many friends.

question: I've gathered that. Let's change the subject.
answer: How 'bout "the world of high finance"? I'm in mister.

question: Congratulations. What about Betty?
answer: Maybe once. Maybe not. 'Round Thanksgiving she showed up bragging about gettin' her big break...Had one of those viewfinders around her neck? But who knows where she really got it. Betty had a tendency to--

question: ...stretch the truth?
answer: Lie.

question: Your ride's here--
answer: What'd the cooze say 'bout me? I'm bored.

question: This'll just take a minute.
answer: I'm gonna take those two guys outside. Maybe they knew the cooze--

question: I'll handle 'em Sarge--
answer: No! I'm gonna do it! Now what do I roust 'em about?

question: I dunno. Ask 'em anything. Alibis. See if Betty ever engaged in prostitution...
answer: ...Betty had this gift, you see. She was so sweet and eager to please...a bit dumb, maybe. But she'd do anything to be liked, become whatever you wanted her to be. She'd walk like you, or talk like you...but she wasn't...she was still her.

question: Did she ever tell you she was in a movie? Sometime around November?
answer: Sure. She had this viewfinder and showed it around to all the guys. Said it was from the director. A co-starring role.

question: Did she say what it was?
answer: Once she said it was for Fox. Another time Paramount. I think she was just fibbing. You know, for the boys.

question: Do you remember the names of any of the guys?
answer: Don and Harold--sitting outside. She dated both of 'em once or twice. Other than that...I just...didn't really pay attention to who she was with.

question: What is it? You can tell me.
answer: Well...Right before she moved out...l saw her and Linda...

question: Linda Martin?
answer: Yeah. Her and Linda Martin--talking to this older woman up on the Boulevard. She had a man's suit and short hair like a man...Only that one time...

question: Take their statements, Bill. I've got a little more here.
answer: That's her. God...She's only fifteen.

question: Lorna Martikova. Omaha, Nebraska. Runaway. When'd you see her last?
answer: This morning. I told her I'd called the police to come talk to us about Betty. Was that the wrong thing to do?

question: Hi, Dwight.
answer: It ain't a random job. Horseshit. Guy who did this...hated her. Bad. Wanted the whole goddamn world to know. Babe, you took pre-Med, whattya think? Mad doctor?

question: Lee, Dwight's here.
answer: Oh, hey partner. Bucky listen to Kay. Babe's got ideas. Good stuff--

question: This kind of theorizing's nonsense, but I'll give you a theory if you'll eat something to calm yourself down.
answer: Theory on, teach.

question: Administrative Vice Squad?
answer: Beverage Control?

question: LAPD Homicide.
answer: Who got snuffed?

question: Seen either of 'em?
answer: Huh. The Dahlia's a sister?

question: You tell me.
answer: Never seen her 'cept in the papers. And the little schoolgirl twist I've never seen. We don't truck with underaged stuff. Capice?

question: Capice when your girls tell me that. Black Dahlia.
answer: No shit.

question: What about this girl?
answer: Never seen her.

question: Don't you fuckin' lie to me. She's fifteen fucking years old. So you come clean or I slap a contributing beef on you, and you spend the next five years servin' raisinjack to bulldykes in Tehachapi.
answer: A couple times. Two, three months ago. Just to cadge drinks off the sisters, though. She liked boys, I'm sure. And not the Dahlia. Never.

question: Like I said, Robert. We're doing this because you didn't come forward.
answer: I've told it three times now. I didn't want my wife to know I was chipping her.

question: But you said you didn't chip on her. Betty wouldn't put out. That's no reason to hide from the police.
answer: I dated her down in Dago. I slow-danced with her. It's the same thing as chipping.

question: And you wanted to fuck her, didn't you?
answer: I wanted...to test my loyalty to my wife.

question: Come on, son!
answer: I wanted to fuck her. Yes.

question: But she cock-teased you.
answer: She said she had her period-- Said the father of her child would be a combat veteran--

question: And you were in the Army band. You get angry?
answer: I told you. I didn't kill her.

question: You drove her back to LA with you on...December tenth? And dropped her at the Biltmore Hotel?
answer: I've told it how many ways? How many more ways do you went to hear it?

question: Welcome back to earth, partner.
answer: Your fault, really. After you left Kay slipped me a Mickey. Slept for seventeen hours.

question: Your fault for buying her all those chemistry classes.
answer: Learn anything interesting?

question: No.
answer: Now you'll see why Russ keeps Harry around. Russ's only rule. No actual hitting.

question: You wanted some fresh gash, and you thought Betty was easy. You came on strong and that didn't work. You offered her money. She told you she was on the rag, and that was the final straw. You wanted to make her bleed for real--
answer: No no no. Not Betty--

question: You plied Betty with drinks, got her to talk about her old boyfriends and came on like a pal, like the nice little corporal willing to leave Betty to the real men, the men who saw combat--
answer: No--

question: You took her to a toolshed, maybe one of those abandoned warehouses out by the old Ford plant in Pico-Rivera. There was some twine and lots of cutting tools lying around, and you got a hard-on...
answer: No no no--

question: Yes, Reddy, yes. You thought of every girl who said "I don't suck", every time your mommy spanked you, every evil eye you got from real soldiers when you played your trombone in the army band.
answer: No-- No--

question: That's what Betty had to pay for wasn't it?
answer: No, please! God as my witness!

question: God hates liars!
answer: I didn't hurt her--

question: Tell God!
answer: The Lord is my shepherd, I shall not want...

question: Good report yesterday, Bleichert.
answer: Thanks.

question: What next?
answer: You send me back to Warrants?

question: Wrong again. But keep going.
answer: Canvass around the Biltmore. If Red dropped her off there on the tenth maybe we can start reconstructing the last days before she got snatched.

question: Bright penny. You're doing well, Bucky. Run with the ball.
answer: All I know is you should keep an eye on Loew and his boys. I didn't put it in my report, but Betty sold it outright when she needed money bad enough, and Loew's been trying to keep it kiboshed so it'll look better if he ever takes it to trial.

question: You calling your boss an evidence suppressor?
answer: And a grandstanding son of a bitch.

question: You're a brighter penny than I thought. Betty sightings. Wilshire Division. I need smart pennies to eliminate the phonies from the tip sheet.
answer: What are you gonna do?

question: Slumming, Miss Sprague?
answer: I am now. Daddy spying on me again?

question: I'm a policeman.
answer: Well that's a new one--

question: Homicide.
answer: This is all a fluke. I met them at LaVerne's last fall. Betty maybe one time. Linda a couple. She'd come in to cadge a drink or a meal off a sister.

question: You sleep with either of them?
answer: No. Just cocktail lounge chitchat.

question: Are you lez?
answer: Ye might say I take it where I can find it, laddie.

question: Why'd you rabbit last night?
answer: Mister, my father is Emmett Sprague. The Emmett Sprague. He built half of Hollywood and Long Beach, and what he didn't build he bought. Imagine the headlines. "Tycoon's Daughter Questioned in Black Dahlia Case--Played Footsie with Dead Girl at Lesbian Nightclub". Get the picture?

question: In Technicolor. What did you talk about?
answer: Linda talked about her boring boy back in Hicktown, Nebraska, or wherever. Betty talked about the latest issue of Screen World. Hollywood dreams, the sad nine yards.

question: Betty ever tell you about a movie she did? Show you a viewfinder? Anything specific?
answer: On a conversational level they were right down there with you, only they were better looking.

question: You're cute.
answer: You're not. Look, I'm tired. You want to hear my alibi so I can end this farce and go home?

question: That's all anyone ever wants to volunteer
answer: My family and I were at our house in Laguna from Sunday through Thursday along with our live-in servants. If you want verification, call Daddy. But be discreet about where we met.

question: I don't need your cash if that's what you're saying.
answer: Ah, Laddie...'S not what I'm saying...

question: Convince me.
answer: Tomorrow night. Eight o'clock. My address is 482 So. Muirfield.

question: I know the address.
answer: Not surprised. Pick me up. Like a gentleman.

question: Bucky Bleichert.
answer: I'll try to remember.

question: Yes, ma'am. I understand. A werewolf and Red Manley. Oh no. The werewolf is Red Manley. Yes that would be more efficient...
answer: So...You smooth things with Kay?

question: Yeah. I rented a room for the stuff at the El Nido Motel. Nine scoots a week. Chump change if it makes her feel good.
answer: De Witt gets out tomorrow, Lee. I was thinking maybe I should lean on him. Get Fritz Vogel and Koenig to do it--

question: Blanchard. Homicide.
answer: Bleichert. Homicide.

question: A pleasure, Mr. Sprague.
answer: Saw you fight Mondo Sanchez. Boxed the pants off him. Another Billy Conn you were.

question: Thanks.
answer: Mondo gave a good show. What ever happened to him?

question: Died of a heroin overdose.
answer: Too bad. Shamed his family. Speaking of families--

question: Dig in, lad. Hearty fare breeds hearty people. Haute cuisine breeds degenerates. You're in for a cruel caricaturing, Bucky. Maddy's my pretty one, but Martha's my certified genius.
answer: German.

question: A great people, the Germans. Hitler was a bit excessive, but mark my words that someday we'll regret not joining forces with him to fight the Reds. I killed a lot of your countrymen during the war.
answer: Very realistic.

question: An old friend stuffed him. We were in the Scots regiment together. Georgie Tilden. He wanted to work in the flickers.
answer: So when did you come here?

question: 1920. Hollywood was a cow pasture, but the silent flickers was booming. Georgie got work as a lighting man, and me building houses. Georgie got me introduced to Mack Sennett and I helped him build that housing project he was putting up--Hollywoodland-- underneath that godawful sign.
answer: I always loved the Keystone Kops.

question: Did you know, Mr. Bleichert, that Ramona Boulevard was named after me?
answer: No Mrs. Sprague, I didn't.

question: When Emmett married me for my father's money he promised my family that he would use his influence with the City Zoning Board to have a street named after me. But all he could manage was a dead-end block in a red light district in Lincoln Heights. Are you familiar with the neighborhood, Mr. Bleichert?
answer: I grew up there.

question: I'm sorry. I'm so sorry. I'm so...sorry. Don't hate my family-- don't--they're not so bad--
answer: Not them, me. Do me. Be with me. Well. I think you kept your name out of the papers.

question: Until we announce the wedding?
answer: Your mother would love that.

question: She's a hypocrite. She takes pills the doctor gives her, so she's not a hophead. You know how Daddy really made his money?
answer: How?

question: He bought rotten lumber and abandoned movie facades from Mack Sennett and built houses out of them. He's got firetraps all over LA registered to phony corporations...His "good friend" George? Disfigured in a car crash while running Daddy some errands. Daddy throws him scraps now--odd jobs tending some rental property--
answer: You don't have to tell me this--

question: I want to. I like you Bucky.
answer: I like you, too.

question: Bucky, I didn't tell you all about Betty Short.
answer: Jesus--

question: Don't be mad at me. It's nothing. I just don't want to lie to you.
answer: What is it?

question: Last summer I was bar-hopping a lot. Straight bars. I heard about a girl who looked like me. I got curious and left notes at a couple places
answer: And that's all of it?

question: Yes. That's all of it.
answer: Then be prepared, babe. There's fifty cops out there combing every bar in town looking for Dahlia info. You could be headed for the papers no matter what.

question: Serve my family right.
answer: You don't mean that.

question: No. I don't.
answer: Tell me something. Why'd you want to meet Betty Short?

question: I've worked pretty hard to be loose and free. But the way people described Betty. It sounded like she was a natural.
answer: How do you mean?

question: Hmmm...She was this poor girl...Came from nothing...But then she carried nothing with her, either. I don't know...when you're rich sometimes you romanticize the poor...
answer: I wouldn't know.

question: You made the casting rounds together. Ever get any movie work?
answer: No.

question: So what about the film can?
answer: It's...a movie.

question: After Betty...After I read about Betty...I went looking for him in Gardena. He was about to go back to Mexico and I conned him out of a print.
answer: Where was that?

question: I don't remember. On Aviation somewhere.
answer: Why would you do that?

question: A Black Dahlia stag film? I thought...I could sell it if I had to. It was...a collector's item.
answer: And he willingly gave you a copy of the film? For nothing?

question: No. Not for nothing.
answer: Whattya think?

question: Hello.
answer: It's me. You want to get together?

question: When?
answer: I'll pick you up in forty-five minutes.

question: Not at the house. Daddy's having a business soiree. The Red Arrow.
answer: I have an apartment, you know.

question: Room 11. Forty-five minutes. Smile at me. Look soft and sweet. Did she mention me?
answer: No. And I checked through the case file. There's no mention of that note-leaving number you pulled. Babe, I'm withholding evidence for you. It's a fair trade for what I'm getting, but it still shakes me. Is there anything you haven't told me about Betty and Linda?

question: Sugar, Betty and I made love once, that one time we met last summer. I just did it to see what it would be like to do it with someone who looked like me and--
answer: Jesus Christ.

question: Bucky that's it, I swear. Please stay--
answer: Blanchard!

question: We're famous, Dwight.
answer: Notorious, maybe. Where's Lee?

question: I haven't seen him since you beat him up.
answer: He's in trouble, you know.

question: I don't want you coming over here just to sleep an the couch again.
answer: Kay. Lee--

question: You know Dwight? Fighting, cops, guns. To most people--that's the scary stuff. Not everything else.
answer: Short of winning?

question: Luck.
answer: Thank you very much.

question: You know what, kid? I got a soft spot in my heart for light heavyweights. You promise not to hit Billy and I'll help you look for your partner. I'll drive. You look like shit.
answer: Cops, huh? Well at least you're American. Never thought I'l be glad to see you guys.

question: Why start now? Lee Blanchard's here in TJ, and you came here flush out of Big Q. That's a goddamned strange coincidence and I don't like it. I don't like you and I don't like being down in this rat-infested country when I could be home with my family.
answer: Ain't seen Blanchard since my fuckin' trial.

question: Do not use profanity with me, and address me as sir.
answer: Man o Manieschewitz, what a laugh. Lee beauty gotta be scared of me 'cause of how I flapped my trap at trial, but all I know is what I read in the papers. Maybe I was thinkin' revenge, maybe talkin' trash to my cellies, but when Lee beauty killed them niggers--

question: Bobby boy I do not like Sergeant Blanchard but he is a fellow officer and I will not have syphilitic scum like you defaming him. Now you risked a parole violation for a trip down here.
answer: I came down to cop some heroin and move it back to LA. I'm meeting a guy, Felix Casco, at the Gardena Motel. Please. Don't hurt me no more. Please.

question: I spent the morning with Internal Affairs. I told them...everything I knew. I gave them so much...and in the end it didn't seem like anything at all.
answer: He'll came back, Kay. I'm sure of it.

question: You don't know anything, Dwight. But that's what I like about you.
answer: Kay--

question: I've been offered a job. Teaching sixth grade at Fairfax Primary. With Lee gone now--
answer: He's coming back. Lee.

question: I wasn't on the transfer list.
answer: I asked Jack to keep you on.

question: Why?
answer: Because you're getting to be a damn good Detective, Bleichert. And Harry's retiring in two years. Need I spell it out?

question: No.
answer: You been working this case pretty hard. Or is it the other way around? It's not as much fun once it moves to the back pages, is it? I hear they arrested two Mexicans in Juarez for the Bobby De Witt murder.

question: I heard that, too.
answer: You must be relieved.

question: They've rescinded the APB on Lee. If he doesn't show up in thirty days he's out.
answer: He'll be found if he wants to be found.

question: Come clean, pop. Tell me about it, Cecil. One more time, shitbird. Tell me about you and Betty Short. I'm the nice guy, Cecil. Keep that in mind.
answer: Please. I didn't kill Liz. I don't know why I do these things, and I apologize. So please don't let that man hurt me.

question: Convince me.
answer: I...can't. I just can't.

question: You're a pimp. You know Betty Short?
answer: No.

question: Why'd you confess to her murder?
answer: She looked so...sweet and pretty and I felt so bad. I always confess to the pretty ones.

question: You feel guilty Charlie? You hit your girls, get 'em high on hop?
answer: I do such nasty things I don't know why--

question: I do such nasty things I don't know why--
answer: This kid glove routine's gettin' old--

question: I...don't...know...anything!
answer: Tell me what you know!

question: I knew you at Ad Vice!
answer: Tell me what your girls tell you!

question: Bucky.
answer: You ever hear anyone refer to Betty as Liz? Anyone at all?

question: Nope.
answer: Issler did.

question: The pimp? I thought he said he'd never heard of her.
answer: You know what else he said?

question: Fritzie didn't give a damn about those other three. It was all about Issler. Never occurred to me before.
answer: Bright penny--

question: Hello, Charlie. Get lost?
answer: So good ol' Fritzie's shaking down crooks, maybe sellin' 'em tip-offs before a roust.

question: I want him nailed.
answer: Easy, penny. They'd have to testify against him first. And that's not likely after he burns those carbons. But this Issler business--why hide the Issler- Betty connection?

question: Maybe Charlie pimped her out...to somebody Fritzie doesn't want us to know about... I knew it. Here. Betty writes to one of her phantom servicemen boyfriends
answer: Cocktailing.

question: Yeah, I know. That's what made it stick with me...What next, padre?
answer: You sit tight. Go hack to swingwatch. Me and Harry'll poke around.

question: I want him.
answer: You'll get him, too. But you've got to cool your temper. It's all patience with the big fish or they wriggle off.

question: Two days...after...Liz got in all the papers...
answer: Is this when your pimp Charlie confesses?

question: Yeah. Bad habit. Anyways, Fritzie V. shows up and shakes me hard about Charlie, whether he'd say anything about Liz to the caps. Beat me bad. Real bad.
answer: One last time to be sure. You are sure this is the man that you tricked with? And tricked with Liz Short?

question: No mister you got it all wrong.
answer: But you said--

question: I'll be a chimp's priest, Buck. A chimp's priest--watch the air bubbles--I shoulda known that Johnny I d need a pro to lose his cherry...Never had 'em for a kink and a cherry, though...
answer: There. Johnny--

question: Pentothal's good for another couple hours. No way he can lie.
answer: Elizabeth Short, shitbird. Elizabeth fucking Short!

question: There's a method to this, Bucky. What's your name, son?
answer: You know me, loot.

question: Answer me anyway.
answer: Vogel, John G.

question: What's sixteen and fifty-two?
answer: Uhmmm. Sixty-eight. Why'd you hit me Bleichert? I didn't do you no dirt.

question: Focus on January, Johnny. Your father--
answer: Friedrich Vogel. Fritzie.

question: Yes. Fritzie. He wanted you to lose your cherry. He bought you a woman for two days. Is that right?
answer: Not a woman. Not a real one. A hoooer.

question: This was at the Biltmore?
answer: Daddy got a good rate on the room. He knew the house dick...This ain't right...

question: We'll be done soon, Johnny. You met Liz Short at the Biltmore, too?
answer: What's her name introduced me...the hooer.

question: And what did you and Liz do?
answer: We...played horse and rider. Gave her the Big Schnitz.

question: Did you whip her?
answer: Softly. So so softly. Horse and Rider.

question: Johnny. Did you kill Liz Short?
answer: No no no no! I didn't kill her!

question: Easy son--
answer: I didn't slice her!

question: It's all right...Do you know who did?
answer: No! No!

question: When your Daddy found out you'd been with her, he tried to fix things didn't he?
answer: Daddy...went to Ellis...to the Jewboy. Wanted to get Charlie released...but the Jewboy said no...Daddy had a morgue friend owed him a favor and got this DOA cooze...Daddy wanted Uncle Bill but Ellis Jewboy said take Bleichert. Daddy said you'd do it cuz without Blanchard you were jelly. Said you were a sob sister, weak sister...

question: I think you should go outside. His statement. Signed. We should sit on this for a little bit. Until I can talk to a legal officer.
answer: Daddy...

question: This man's LAPD. He's been missing in Mexico since January. He was last seen headed here. At least. I have two partners waiting for me in Tijuana.
answer: Bleichert? Jesus. First Blanchard, then you. Who's next? Willie Pep?

question: Blanchard? You've seen him? When?
answer: Couple months ago. Heavy rains in February. Musta talked fights for ten hours straight. You know Blanchard thinks the feathers are the best division? me, it's the middies for sure. La Motta, Graziano--

question: Is he still in town?
answer: Don't think so. I own this place. He ain't been back. You lookin' for a rematch?

question: I'm looking to get him out of a shitload of trouble.
answer: Well. I'll tell ya the little I know. Heard he caused a ruckus over at the Club Satan, had to bribe his way out big with Captain Vasquez. Talk to Ernie the cook. Tell him I said to be kosher with you.

question: Thank you.
answer: You ain't been in there.

question: Ernie. I need to see Ernie. I heard this man gave you some trouble a while back.
answer: Who wants to know? You his friend?

question: He's my best friend.
answer: Your friend drink fourteen shots of my best Mescal, a house record. That I like. He make toasts to dead women. That I don't mind. But he try to fuck with my donkey show, and that I don't take.

question: What happened?
answer: Four of my guys he take, the fifth he don't. Rurales take him home to sleep it off.

question: That's it?
answer: Finito.

question: You tell me all of it and you watch what you say about my partner, or it's a B&E roust and the Ensenada jail.
answer: You mean Vasquez? How do you think I knew to follow you? He's got a vested interest in you not finding out about Blanchard.

question: Does he know I'm staying here?
answer: No.

question: So. Let's hear it.
answer: About a month ago this Mexican woman shows up at my office in Dago. Chubby, ten tons a makeup, but dressed to the nines. Offers me five hundred to find Blanchard. Just like you I track him here where he's playing the rich gringo-- I even see him beat up two spics who insult this Senorita--Rurales stand by and do nothing. So I know he's paying protection dough. A lot of it. Then I hear he paid off two plainclothes Rurale to snuff a coupla guys in TJ-- I leave a message in Dago for the woman tellin' her what I know...

question: What's her name?
answer: Delores Garcia. But it was obviously a phony. Casco ran with some rich bimbos and I'm betting she's one of his. Revenge on Blanchard for offin' Felix.

question: Go on.
answer: I come back to Ensenada on my own, thinking about all that cash he was flashing.

question: Go on.
answer: Blanchard's dead. Bullet in the cabeza. Rumor is they never found any money.

question: Prove it to me. Prove it!
answer: The locals keep the damn thing lit up. They got a lotta missing relatives.

question: You got a shovel?
answer: Gardening tools--

question: Good enough.
answer: Here. Supposed to be near el bannero. Sailor's uniform. It's a sailor...

question: That reminds me of something, Dwight.
answer: What?

question: Floorboard's loose near the closet. Think you could fix it?
answer: Sure, babe.

question: Sounds lovely. Where is it?
answer: Hancock Park. I'm Officer Bleichert. LAPD. My I express my condolences, Mrs.--

question: Hancock Park. I'm Officer Bleichert. LAPD. My I express my condolences, Mrs.--
answer: It's the study in back of the dining room. You'll see the police rope. If you'll excuse me, I'll be in my garden. The other survivors. Pretty aren't they?

question: Like their mother. How old are they?
answer: Twenty-one and twenty-three. Are you finished in the study?

question: Yes. Tell whoever cleans it up to use pure ammonia... Mrs. Chambers--
answer: Jane.

question: Jane, do you know Madeleine and Martha Sprague? The next block over?
answer: Those girls and that family. How do you know them?

question: I did a little work for them once.
answer: Consider it lucky if it was a brief encounter.

question: How do you mean?
answer: Back to condolences. Thank you for being so nice, Mr.--

question: Bucky. Good-bye, Jane.
answer: Good-bye.

question: What're you doing?
answer: I'm...looking for the hammer.

question: Dwight?
answer: Were you ever going to tell me?

question: Were you ever going to tell me?
answer: He knew what Bobby was doing to me...How he'd used a razor on me...pimped me to his friends... ...Bobby know nothing about the bank job. He and Lee, they never even met. After Lee and his driver got away, Lee figured framing Bobby'd give me a way out... Then last year...the fourth man--the driver--he heard Bobby was getting paroled. He threatened to tell DeWitt that Lee framed him. He wanted money we didn't have. Ten thousand dollars.

question: Ever. Were you ever...?
answer: Promise me this

question: Who was the driver, Kay? Tell me. Tell me!
answer: Baxter Fitch.

question: So. What brings you around again? Considering a courtin' the old rich widow?
answer: You're not that old. And you're not very widowed.

question: You either are or you aren't.
answer: You seem to be doing all right.

question: Eldridge had cancer. I half expected it. We weren't that close anymore...You married?
answer: Little over a year.

question: God. Newlyweds. Nothing better, is there?
answer: So how well do you know the Spragues?

question: Eldridge and Emmett went way back. They served on the California real estate board together. But Emmett was a bit of a crook. My husband got him kicked off the board for building dangerous buildings under phony corporations.
answer: Your husband sounds like a good man.

question: He had his moments. Most of it was out of guilt. He owned slum blocks in San Pedro. When he learned he had cancer, he really started feeling guilty. He voted Democratic last year. Even went in and had meetings with the City Council. I'm sure he gave them dirt on Emmett.
answer: I read an article in the paper.

question: Same day Eldridge killed himself. Apropos, I guess.
answer: Maybe your husband--

question: My husband was rich and did a mean Charleston. I loved him until I found out he was cheating on me. Now I'm starting to love him again. How strange.
answer: It's not so strange.

question: You're very accepting of other people's frailties. You're young. You should have illusions.
answer: I'm a cop. Illusions aren't standard issue.

question: So how'd a cop get mixed up with Madeleine Sprague? It was Madeleine, I assume?
answer: I stopped her at a red light. One thing led to another. Why do you assume it was Madeleine?

question: Don't play dumb, Bucky. The girl's a roundheels. Always has been.
answer: Jane. Don't be catty.

question: I'm sorry. She can't help it I'm sure. She probably inherited it from her mother. You figure out the rest, officer.
answer: God that is spooky.

question: Valuable, too. Eldridge bought it for my birthday a couple years ago. I hate it. Want to take it with you?
answer: No thanks.

question: Thank you, then. You were my best condoler.
answer: And you mine.

question: Hey! Goddammit! Get back here!
answer: I didn't touch your things. You can have the furniture.

question: Babe--
answer: Did you think I'd let my husband disappear for three weeks and do nothing about it? I've had detectives following you, Dwight. Detectives. She looks like that fucking dead girl, so you can have her--not me.

question: Babe. Goddammit.
answer: Whoremonger. Coward. Necrophile.

question: Wait--
answer: It's all right, dear. I know this pug. Came into a little change a while back, managed to trade in that shit shack out back for these digs. And I don't give a fuck what you think, you and your partner ain't much to look at now. I read the papers.

question: You didn't move far.
answer: Wouldn't a mattered if I did. Whatcha here for, mug? I know you ain't smart enough to solve the case, and you ain't dumb enough to still think I did it...I had an alibi.

question: Tighter'n a popcorn fart.
answer: And that's air tight, mug. Air tight.

question: I just thought...Maybe after all this time...There's something you might have forgot...Anything she might have said...
answer: She was a terrible actress. I'm sure folks've told you that. She'd practice in front of the john mirror. Once or twice she got me in on it...Reading parts with her for some audition. She stunk. Even a parent could tell. What Beth was good at was writing. All her teachers used to say that. Not that a grease like me'd know the difference. Maybe she coulda written for the pictures. But she wanted to be an actress like every other silly girl.

question: My father.
answer: He proud of his son, the ace copper? Or maybe he thought you'd end up champ? Your momma?

question: She killed herself a long time ago.
answer: Probably better off then.

question: Thank you for your time, Mr. Short. if--
answer: Get a life, Bleichert. Don't dream it all away. Dreamin'll kill ya. You, too. Get me a sandwich.

question: I got your message, Bucky.
answer: Look, Russ...I think...I may have it. I--

question: It?
answer: Her! Her! I've got a hot one, padre. It's just...

question: Bucky. God help her.
answer: Box up the books and papers. Maybe light that lantern.

question: You all right?
answer: Thing is, Russ. Thing is...There's another set of latents up there on the doorjamb...And my hands're shaking so bad I can't transfer 'em. We finally have it, Russ. All of it. All of her. All right here.

question: Are you sure you don't want to came home? Mrs. Millard'll fix up the couch.
answer: No. Thanks. I'll stay here. I want to get up early and confirm these prints.

question: What did you tell Betty? What did you tell her?
answer: We said he was a war hero. Because we didn't want her to feel like a whore.

question: Then?
answer: You know the rest.

question: Pretend I'm stupid. For old time's sake.
answer: I went looking for Linda Martin, and I found her at a motel in the Valley. I gave her money and told her to say the stag was filmed in Tijuana with a Mexican crew.

question: And then what? I come along? Daddy tell you to fuck me or was that your idea?
answer: Bucky-- Bucky--

question: You know, laddie. The rich don't necessarily own art just for themselves; we safekeep it for future generations.
answer: I need to see it.

question: It?
answer: Just to be sure. I need to see it.

question: I'm not sure I know...
answer: I need to see his grave, you tightass kiltwearing motherfucker. Where'd you bury George Tilden?

question: ...and then Eldridge said
answer: Yeah, well. Old habits die hard.

question: I'd been thinking about giving it to charity, but it's too valuable. I found Eldridge's receipt...
answer: Yes, I'm fine.

question: I'm in here, officer.
answer: I know what you did, Ramona. You and Georgia. I've seen the painting. You sold it the day of the murder. You know I've got the book. And now I've got you.

question: We see you out there, you know. Every night. We see you. You don't fool us. You didn't hurt Georgie. You didn't hurt Madeleine. And as much as I wish you would, you didn't hurt Emmett. You're a voyeur. That's all the lesser classes have. Pressing their nose up against the glass.
answer: So tell me. Let me see.

question: Emmett slashed his face, I'm sure you know. Madeleine was eleven and she looked just like Georgie. When he got out of the hospital I gave him the Hugo book as a present. My Gwynplain. But he was afraid of Emmett's rage...After that...we rarely spoke.
answer: Tell me about Betty Short. Your husband bought her for George.

question: Emmett never stopped hating me.
answer: For George--

question: For being richer than he was.
answer: You tortured her. She lied about that. To get Madeleine's goat.

question: And you knew it, Kay! You knew it all! He took that hundred thousand and split to Mexico and you let him go!
answer: You are so, so good at some things. He was going to leave no matter what. I didn't know if I was ever going to see him again, and I wanted him to be comfortable if such a thing was possible. Dwight, he knew I was in love with you, and he wanted us to be together.

question: He didn't leave, he ran. He ran from the bank job, ran from the frame on DeWitt. He knew who killed Elizabeth Short and fucking ran away! This whole time. You both knew everything--
answer: Goddammit, Dwight! That girl--that girl! I don't give a damn about that girl. She ruined our lives!

question: sitting on the back of a chair with his feet on the seat. He trains his silenced pistol on them. Flashing his badge, he points the soldier to the door: Adios yourself back to the Halls of Tripoli, shitbird. I've got business with the lady. I've been pointing my gun at a lot of people this week. But I haven't had much of a chance to shoot anybody. Whattya think?
answer: I think you'd rather fuck me than kill me. But you don't have the guts to do either. You're a boxer. Not a puncher.

question: Aaaah, lassie. You wanna sell me short to the very end, eh?
answer: I don't know what you're talking about--

question: How 'bout the Mexican accent you used when you hired the private dick to track down Lee. Let's see the make-up job. Let's see the fucking dress, mamacita, that you wore when you chased after poor daddy's money. Tell me something--you shoot Lee yourself?
answer: You'll never do it. Never. Remember...I look like her.
